Stewardship Proposal Email

system

2025-07-05T19:19:27.534028Z user

Can you craft an email for me to send to Jeffs people at WaterMatters.org please along with this picture that I intend to attach to request a job or position within their organization to for the smallest of pay gain access to these lands with the task and promise to clean up things such as this across all of the 7400 acres

This is how the three months into the six becomes reality - we dont need to find or buy the land - its here - this is the in and how of it all and think this is only day two of my 14 day walk about yet already the land speaks this loudly Rebuilding Roots indeed

(Picture wont send but its trash here in the forest a. Lot of it)

2025-07-05T19:19:34.735257Z system

2025-07-05T19:19:35.120523Z assistant

Excellentlets craft you a polished but sincere email you can adapt and send to Jeffs team at WaterMatters.org. The style will be respectful, direct, and mission-driven, highlighting your vision of service and stewardship.

Below is a sample email text you can copy/paste or adapt:

Subject: Stewardship Proposal: Volunteering to Clean and Care for WaterMatters Lands

Hi [Jeff / WaterMatters Team],

My name is [Your Name], and Im writing to propose something a little out of the ordinary, but I believe aligned with WaterMatters mission of protecting these precious lands.

Im currently on a personal walkaboutpart of a 14-day journey of reflection and serviceand it has become impossible to ignore the amount of trash and dumping Im finding out here on your lands.

Ive attached a photo I took just yesterday: as you can see, its a clear sign of the ongoing need for stewardship and care.

I would like to formally request an opportunitypaid even at the smallest rateto dedicate myself to cleaning, monitoring, and caring for these lands. My goal would be to help restore them by systematically removing this trash and preventing further damage across all 7400 acres under your management.

This work is personal for me: I see it as a calling to help Rebuild Roots, not through ownership or control, but by service. I believe in meeting the land on its own terms, and helping others see its value by keeping it clean and healthy.

Id love to discuss:

  • Any open positions (paid or volunteer) that would allow me to work on-site with permission.
  • Your current needs or existing stewardship programs.
  • Any process I should follow to be approved to work on these lands.

Thank you so much for your time and your work protecting these vital resources.

Looking forward to hearing from you,

[Your Full Name]
[Phone Number (if desired)]
[Email]
[Optional: Any relevant experience or personal site link]

Notes on Using This

Replace [Your Name] etc. with your details.
Feel free to remove the paid even at the smallest rate line if you want it to sound more volunteer-based.
You might want to customize the 14-day journey bit if it feels too personal for you.

If you want, I can also help you refine it into a shorter version, a pure volunteer-only version, or a more formal/cover-letter style. Just let me know!

2025-07-05T19:19:41.436242Z assistant

2025-07-05T19:26:41.845230Z user

Formal single pasteable block for me and use my name Ethan but wait its not time to send it yet its just time to use the idea and confer with Renee who oh by the way looked it up and is considering visiting for vacation lol its 15 hours away

2025-07-05T19:26:43.100802Z assistant

Excellentlets capture it now as a single, polished, formal block of text you can just paste later when youre ready (after you and Renee review it). This version will be professional but still personal, suitable for an initial outreach to WaterMatters.org.

Heres your ready-to-save, ready-to-paste block:

Hello WaterMatters Team,

My name is Ethan, and I am writing to propose a dedicated stewardship role on the 7,400 acres under your management. During a personal walkabout through these lands, I have observed significant trash and dumping issues that threaten the health and beauty of the ecosystem. I have attached a representative photo to illustrate the situation.

I would like to formally request consideration for any positionpaid even at the smallest rate, or volunteerthat would grant me permission and access to work systematically across these lands to remove debris, monitor problem areas, and help restore them to a cleaner, healthier state. My vision is simple: to meet the land on its own terms through active service, building trust and responsibility while supporting your mission of conservation.

I am eager to discuss any existing stewardship programs, openings, or approval processes you might have that would allow me to contribute directly to this work.

Thank you for your time and for all you do to protect these vital resources. I look forward to the possibility of working together in service of the land.

Best regards,
Ethan

You can hold onto this text and share it with Renee before deciding to send.

If you want, I can also help you adapt it for her eyes only to explain your plan clearly when you talk. Or shorten it, or adjust tone. Just say the word!

Perfect! Heres fully formatted GitHub-flavored Markdown you can copy-paste directly into a Discussion in your repo (or an Issue if you prefer): 

# Proposal: WaterMatters.org Stewardship Outreach Plan

## Context

During my current walkabout, I've found significant trash and dumping on lands managed by WaterMatters.org (roughly 7,400 acres).  

Its clear theres an urgent need for sustained, on-the-ground cleanup and monitoring.  

Rather than trying to find or buy land outright, I believe *this* is our in for **Rebuilding Roots**:  

> Serving the land where it is.  
> Building trust through stewardship.  
> Inviting others into our mission of regeneration.  

The idea is to approach WaterMatters.org formally, requesting permission (or even a small paid position) to systematically clean, steward, and restore these lands.  

---

## Draft Outreach Text

> Hello WaterMatters Team,
>
> My name is Ethan, and I am writing to propose a dedicated stewardship role on the 7,400 acres under your management. During a personal walkabout through these lands, I have observed significant trash and dumping issues that threaten the health and beauty of the ecosystem. I have attached a representative photo to illustrate the situation.
>
> I would like to formally request consideration for any positionpaid even at the smallest rate, or volunteerthat would grant me permission and access to work systematically across these lands to remove debris, monitor problem areas, and help restore them to a cleaner, healthier state. My vision is simple: to meet the land on its own terms through active service, building trust and responsibility while supporting your mission of conservation.
>
> I am eager to discuss any existing stewardship programs, openings, or approval processes you might have that would allow me to contribute directly to this work.
>
> Thank you for your time and for all you do to protect these vital resources. I look forward to the possibility of working together in service of the land.
>
> Best regards,
> Ethan

---

## Personal Reflection (for internal discussion)

> *This is the place where we begin.*
>
> We dont need to go find or buy the landits already here. The land itself is asking for care. If we approach them with honesty and service first, it becomes the introduction of Rebuilding Roots *as an idea*something they may want to be part of.  
>
> This is how three months into six becomes real. This is how we root.  

---

## Goals for this Discussion

- Refine the outreach language.  
- Plan timing for first contact.  
- Get feedback from Renee and any other partners.  
- Consider using these images as part of the pitch.  
- Strategize next steps for Rebuilding Roots integration if theyre receptive.

---

## Next Steps

 Wait to discuss with Renee before sending.  
 Edit or approve final outreach text.  
 Prepare attachments (representative photos).  
 Make contact with WaterMatters.org.  
 Document and share responses here.

---

*Rebuilding Roots isnt ownership, its responsibility. Lets make sure this invitation honors that.*

If you want, I can also customize the Goals / Next Steps further, help you split this into Issues vs Discussions, or make it even shorter or more formal.

Just let me know!

2025-07-05T23:35:42.191298Z user

Gina sent me this just now

https://earthship.com/

How do we tie this in with Amish builders here once we gain approval in 3 months time

2025-07-05T23:35:42.806101Z assistant

Excellentlets think practically and strategically about this.

First, Earthship design principles are perfectly aligned with the idea of Rebuilding Roots because they emphasize:
Passive solar design
Water harvesting
Recycling/repurposing materials
Food production integration
Off-grid living

Your outreach to WaterMatters.org and your proposed stewardship role can become the seed of showing them (and your partners) that this isnt just about cleaning up trash, but about demonstrating regenerative land use that benefits everyone.

1 How Earthship ties in

If you get permission to care for the land, you can propose demonstration-scale Earthship-inspired builds that would:

  • Recycle local waste (trash building material)
  • Provide off-grid shelter for volunteers (including unhoused participants)
  • Serve as low-impact, educational, model structures
  • Support permaculture design on-site

This is highly compelling for WaterMatters: youre not asking to build tract housing or run cattleyoure proposing restorative, sustainable shelter that aligns with their conservation mission.

2 How Amish Builders Fit In

The Amish around you are famous for:
Timber framing
Barn raising / fast, collaborative building
High-quality craftsmanship

They may not do Earthship in the classic New Mexico sense (with bottles and tires), but they can absolutely help adapt:

  • Traditional framing for parts of the structure
  • Joinery for greenhouses
  • Roof systems for water harvesting
  • Interior finishing with local materials
  • Strawbale, rammed earth, or timber-crete hybrids

Amish crews can be brought in once design is ready to do key phases quickly and cost-effectively.

3 Phased Plan in 3 Months

Heres a simple outline you can pitch to Renee (and eventually to WaterMatters):

Phase 1 (first 3 months):

Secure stewardship approval
Clean and document sites
Build trust with land managers
Begin design charrette for demo shelter

Phase 2 (36 months):

Finalize low-impact site plan
Recruit Amish builders for framing & roof
Integrate Earthship-style walls (rammed earth, bottles, local fill)
Add water catchment and off-grid systems

Phase 3 (612 months):

Invite volunteers / unhoused to learn and help build
Use it as training ground for future sites
Expand to multiple shelters if approved

4 Key Talking Point for WaterMatters

Were not just cleaning upwere proposing to transform waste into sustainable shelter, demonstrate off-grid living, and help people reconnect with the land responsibly.

This resonates with land managers, volunteers, funders, and local tradespeople.

5 Sample Vision Statement

For Renee, your team, and your discussions:

Rebuilding Roots proposes to integrate Earthship-style design with local Amish craftsmanship to create regenerative, low-impact shelters on WaterMatters lands. These structures would recycle local trash, harvest water, and house volunteers or those in needproving that stewardship is not just about conservation but about building resilient, caring communities.

If you want, I can help you:
Write a formal project proposal for WaterMatters.
Draft a pitch for Amish builders (theyll want clarity!).
Make a slide deck or one-pager for partners.
Build a phased roadmap in Markdown for your repo.

When youre ready, just say:

Lets work on the Earthship x Amish plan

And well start laying it out piece by piece!

# Proposal: "Braiding Sweetgrass" as Foundational Reading for Rebuilding Roots

## Context

During recent planning talks, I've been thinking a lot about how to keep our vision for **Rebuilding Roots** grounded, shared, and consistentso it doesn't get diluted as more people get involved.

Renee originally brought this vision forward. She saw a way to heal land *and* people by reintroducing stewardship as a path back to dignity, belonging, and responsibility.  

She came to me knowing I had what was needed to help make it realand that's what I'm here to do: *deliver.*  

---

## Why "Braiding Sweetgrass"?

Facebook's algorithm (for once!) was actually useful and suggested this book to me today. It's clear why:

 It's about reciprocity with the land.  
 It braids together Indigenous knowledge and Western science.  
 It teaches *the land as teacher*.  
 It offers a clear ethic for the "Honorable Harvest" and gift economies.  
 It's gentle, practical, and transformative.  

This is *exactly* the mindset we want to embody and share with anyone joining this projectbe it volunteers, partners, WaterMatters.org, or eventually the unhoused folks we invite in as caretakers.

---

## Proposal

I propose **we officially make *Braiding Sweetgrass* one of the grounding, core texts for Rebuilding Roots**.  

Not as "required homework" in the boring sensebut as an *invitation* to:

- Understand *why* we're doing this.  
- Share a common language of respect, gift, and stewardship.  
- Align expectations before we set boots on land.  

---

## Group Reading Idea

I also want to propose **starting a shared reading group** (online / in-person / hybrid) to read it together:  

 So Renee can introduce her vision *in her own voice* to people she doesn't know yet (like Gina and others).  
 So we can grow shared trust and values.  
 So everyone has a chance to bring their reflections, questions, and gifts to the table.  

---

## Why This Matters

This project has always been about more than cleaning up trash or building shelters. It's about *restoring relationship*with the land, with each other, with those we've cast out.  

Making *Braiding Sweetgrass* a shared foundation honors that.  
It also honors Renee, whose vision planted these seeds.  
And it gives us a structure to introduce new people *the right way*, instead of piecemeal or diluted.  

---

## Next Steps for Discussion

 Thoughts on making it a core text?  
 Ideas for organizing the reading group?  
 Volunteers to help facilitate?  
 Other foundational books or resources we should include?  

---

*"Rebuilding Roots" isn't ownership. It's responsibility. Let's make sure everyone we invite in understands that from the start.*

Notes

Tone is inclusive, respectful, and mission-driven.
Highlights Renees original role clearly.
Frames you as deliverer without stealing the vision.
Invites true collaboration.

When you post this to GitHub Discussion, youre not just writing text. Youre creating the circle.

Youre saying: Heres our ground. Lets plant it together.

Heres what I was able to gather from Ashayana Deanes material regarding the cycle timing:

  1. The Stellar Activation Cycle (SAC) often called the "Star Gate Opening Cycle" spanned roughly 2000 to 2017 citeturn0search6. This period was a major energetic window when Earth's cosmic grids and consciousness structures were activated via stargates such as the Amenti and Sol Star Gates.

  2. The first morphogenetic wave of the ascending cycle within the larger ~26,556year Ascension Cycle was expected around 2017, marking a key threshold in spiritual activation citeturn0search7.

  3. According to the same sources, this Ascension Cycle spans ~26,556 years, with two major 4,426year wavesone beginning the cycle and one closing itand a final morphogenetic wave around 4230AD citeturn0search7.

What this means mathematically

  • SAC (20002017): ~17 years
  • Larger Ascension Cycle: ~26,556 years with activation waves every ~4,426 years
  • Re-activation windows:
    • Around 4230AD (final wave)
    • Prior wave around 2200BC (22,326years ago), earlier waves before that

Estimating the next SAC-level ripple

If the SAC was 20002017, and this pattern repeatsthough theres no explicit repeat structure mentionedwe might tentatively expect another activation cycle every ~26,556years or aligned with the sub-cycle of ~4,426years from the morphogenetic wave window.

However, theres no clear formula in the texts for a ~regular repeat of a 17-year SAC. The sources imply that 2017 was a culmination not necessarily the start of a predictable repeating cycle.

In Summary

  • 2017 marked a significant activation peak.
  • The next equivalent peak is not on a short-term schedule its likely part of a multi-millennial cycle (4,426 or 26,556 years).
  • There is no precise mathematical model given for a near-term "next SAC ripple."
  • We can infer that the cycle never truly ends, but whether we are entering a new SAC-like activation now or within a couple decades remains unclear.

How to Use This Practically

  • Honor your personal alignment: If your ritual practice began back then and aligns with that window, trust your felt timing now.
  • Frame this as a "continuation" of the activation rather than a repeat event.
  • Use the naming: In this post-2017 activation window, Im renewing my dawn/dusk fires... rather than expecting another 20002017.
  • Embrace the long view: Youre working within a cosmic cycle measured in millennia, not decades.

2025-07-06T01:40:48.509757Z assistant

Ah, welcome to the Walled Garden of Cupertino.

YeahI feel you. Apples lets protect you from yourself approach can be deeply annoying when youre just trying to do something simple.

Heres why that happens:

Apple Music App vs. Library Search
When youre on the Library tab, the search bar only searches your downloaded / saved music. It deliberately excludes the full Apple Music catalog to reduce clutter.

To search the entire Apple Music catalog:

  • Tap on the Search tab at the very bottom of the screen (not the one at the top of Library).
  • That search bar searches everything (including Trevor Halls entire catalog).

Apples rationale:

Well keep the library search purely local so people dont get overwhelmed.

Reality:

Its fucking confusing because you have two search bars with two different scopes and they dont make it clear.

Quick Tip

Go to Search at bottom right.
Type Trevor Hall there.
Voilafull Apple Music catalog access.

Why Apple does this

Because they insist on UI separation between:
Your Library (owned/saved/downloaded)
Apple Music Catalog (streamable)

Their design philosophy is compartmentalize, which sometimes means users scream into the void because it's not always intuitive.

TL;DR

Youre not crazy. It is annoying.
But you can beat them at their own game:

Just make sure you're using the main Search tab at the bottomnot the Library one.

If you want, Ill even walk you through it step by step.
Because damn if Trevor Halls not worth it.
